Perfect for a birthday party, date, or just a way to treat yourself to a fun experience.

We went for a school event with students in kindergarten through 8th grade in the middle of the day. Because we went for lunch, we were offered garlic bread, a huge piece of chicken, corn on the cob, potatoes and cookies. They were extremely sensitive towards food allergies, and had plenty of alternatives; for example, they brought out a lemon icee for a student with peanut allergies instead of offering them cookies and/or nothing. They provided coffee to the adults, and brought out more food for students who were picky about one thing or another. Overall, they were very kind and patient to our many demands. The food wasn't spectacular, but it was fun to eat with our hands and get messy! 

The show was super entertaining for the kiddos. Everybody wears a crown with the color of the knight they are voting for, and the Knights pass out flowers (that they kiss hahaha) to various members of their fan group. They had multiple choice questions about anti-bullying and kindness, and really got the kiddos engaged in those tougher topics. Fortunately for us, the green knight won and we were on the green team, so our school went wild! We were also able to take pictures with all of the knights, the princess and the King after the show. 

Overall, I'm not sure I would have loved it had it not been a school function. It's definitely kid-oriented and a fun family affair, but not necessarily something I would do with a group of friends! I would highly recommend it for another school field trip though!

Ehhhh it's good to see that I'm not the only Yelper on here.  My wife's niece wanted to go to medieval times so we took her for her birthday back in November.  The show was entertaining, but kinda cheesy.  I was a LORD if only for a few hours.  They recommend that you get there @ 6:30 pm a full hour before they let you into your assigned seats.  I guess they want you to buy stuff that you don't really need.  There were some pretty cool weapons like swords, shields, armor from different periods.  I am kind of obsessed with this stuff even though I don't need them

The food they served was pretty mediocre.  I never knew that dragon parts tasted so much like regular food. 

The show was ok, but our Red Knight was the runner up.  Kind of like kissing your sister.  So we went from being Lords & Ladies during the show to being normal schleps afterwards.  Oh well Cie la vie.

Checked this place out because the girlfriend wanted to go here and got discounted tickets. They let you in before the show so you can buy overpriced items and drinks. The drinks aren't that bad if you don't get the "fancy souvenir glass" no craft beer so I settled on a $8 new castle my gf got a double Long Island which he didn't know how to make so basically just poured a bunch of booze in a couple with ice she was ok with it so whatever I wasn't drinking it and she said it was good but it was $18

From my understanding the menu hasn't changed in years. You start off with tomato soup and garlic bread. Followed by a chicken leg quarter, potato and for desert a apple turnover. 

Chicken was good but you need to bring hot sauce if you want it. I was starving so I ate all of it and it was a big portion. The potato was cooked all the way in my opinion so didn't really eat that. And didn't care for the apple turnover. 

The show was somewhat entertaining and is really cool for kids. Probably something you could check out every three to five years and look for discounts. Food isn't band but your basically there for the show anyways!

Last time I came here I was probably around 11 years old. So most of what I remember was flashing lights, knights in different colors, and some food you eat with your hands. This time around was pretty much the same thing.

My dad had a hankering for this place since he recently became an intense Game of Thrones fan. So we [my sister and I] decided we can make this a fun outing for him for fathers day. 

They had a cute Father's Day package going on where he gets a free picture, a cape, and a souvenir 24oz beer mug [filled with the good stuff]. That was cute.

The rest of my experience wasn't so cute. The show seemed cheesy, the food was flavorful but we had no options for meat or sides. The whole place started with very watery tomato soup and garlic bread. Then for the main course we had baby dragon [1/2 bone-in chicken] which, to me, seemed precooked and re-heated for the masses. Main course was accompanied by corn and a "dragon egg" which was just 1/2 baked potato. For dessert we got something resembling a less sweet version of apple pie (forgot the "medieval" name they used for it, sorry). To have the "full experience" you were supposed to eat with your hands. I asked for silverware. 

We sat in the section for the yellow knight. We lost the third or fourth round. Very cheesy loss. He got "stabbed". My dad was very into it... but it was Father's Day so that was the point right? 

Something to note here for my fellow booze lovers: the wench who brings you food doesn't serve you alchohol so you have to keep your eyes peeled for one or two other people who walk around and take orders. They do have some cool themed drinks. My favorite was "Maidens Kiss" which was a fruity vodka based drink that had some strawberrry and other fruity falvors mixed in.

Overall I would recommend this place mostly to younger people who have some free time on their hands and want to try something new. My dad had fun but people ages 18-35 who don't have kids might not think agree. Maybe when it opened 20+ years ago the idea was more polished but, ironially, the idea might be a little outdated or appeals to a more specific crowd.

P.S. I wasn't a huge fan of all the tricks, kicks, and prancing they have their horses do.. I don't agree with animals being used for entertainmenet.

A lot of fun but soooo expensive. Went for my birthday, I like to do random things.  Anyway, the price per ticket on the website can be reduced with certain codes and coupons, you just have to seek them out but then they hit you will all sort of taxes and fees. It's pretty abhorrent. 

Anyway, once we got there, it was a lot of fun.  It's super corny and some of the jousting acting is not spot on, but this is not Broadway, after all. It's just a good time, if you let yourself get into it. Buy a flag, root for your knight and ignore any lame people that are inspecting for perfection instead of fun. 

The food was surprisingly good for how much they are putting out all at once. You get to eat with your hands and drink expensive dragon's blood. Overall, we had a really good time.
Great value, entertaining for kids and adults, food is decent, for the price it's a very good outing for the family.

Always a nostalgic hit for young and old. They have a concept and commit to it 100%. The venue is a giant friggin castle complete with a dungeon amd horse stable. Im always surprised to find that they actually have decent food. Our meal consisted of half chicken, tomato soup, corn, garlic bread, and an apple turnover. The portions used to be bigger back in the day, but they are still plenty filling. You eat with your hands, and that never gets old.

The show is a tacky jousting tournament, but because they give you teams to cheer for, you always feel engaged. You can never get too old to buy a $2 flag and wave that bad boy with abandon while your hero wields his lance. Sadly for us, our green knight was an early elimination. Maybe next time.

Extended my family's stay in Chicago for a day just so they could experience Medieval Times, and I have to say it definitely lived up to expectations!  The family (wife, 9 yr old boy and 3 yr old girl) had a blast and even got personally thanked by our knight for our enthusiastic support which only added to the appreciation they had for the evening's entertainment.

All the folks already discuss the meals and options on here, so to the staff who read these, THANK YOU for your amazing and wonderful customer service and truly a unique and fun experience.  To you yelpers who are on the fence about going, GO! If for nothing else than the experience (unless of course you hate the medieval time period and people playing knights & princesses).

And since this apparently is a thing, heard several individuals around me talking about 'taking the gym' which I'm told is a pokemon go reference, soooo there's a gym to be won for all you pokemon go'ers.

The whole experience was fun!! My husband and I wanted to go for part of our honeymoon experience and it couldn't have been better. Everyone was so cheery and the drinks and the food were good, too! You eat with your hands and there are separate people aside from your server who takes your order from the bar. Worth every penny! I had been when I was about 8 and today was just as terrific as the memories.

I went to Medieval Times for the first time ever a few months back and I was pleasantly surprised at how much fun I had.  The performers really get into character and do a fantastic job getting the audience involved.  The food there was also very good and the portions are huge.  I just wished they'd offer utensils because the wet napkins leaves your fingers so sticky.  Also, the prices can be a bit high at the door so look for a good deal online and order in advance if possible.  I can't wait to be back!

After several years driving along I90, passing this place by, I finally went to Medival times with my family to celebrate my dad's 73rd birthday! I like the concept of a dinner show and thought it would be a unique experience for all of us since neither one of us have ever gone to Medival times.

So I've heard this place can get pricey. Had I not had the groupon, it would have set me back 69.95 per person. With the groupon, general admission is $40 pp but it can easily become $60 pp with the additional "add-ons." Are you celebrating a special occasion? Well there's a package for that and you get a cake, an announcement scroll and special mention during the show for an additional $16. Okay fine. I'm cool with that. Do you want to sit closer to the main ring? Well that will cost you an additional $20.00 pp for VIP seating... Pictures with the king or princess cost $20 for one professional photo and $30 for 2. Waving banners cost between $2-5. If you have kids they're going to want whatever light up flashy thing they are going to sell them and those are at least $20+ each. Beer in a goblet? Not sure how much that was but my husband said it was overpriced. If you had to reserve money to spend here, at least tip your servers. I've heard a range of 2-6 dollars per person.

The service is excellent and the food as other Yelpers had mentioned is amazing. You get a starter course of dragon blood (tomato soup) along with some good garlic bread. Then it's off to the mains. With the mains, you are given a generous portion of roast chicken (the call it roast dragon, which by the way was absolutely succulent and delicious!) As soon as I ripped through "the dragon" with  my hands, roasted chicken juice gushed out of the chicken meat. Yum! There was so much chicken left over that I took half of it home with me! With your meal you also get a corn on the cob with a roasted potato. Omg was that potato seasoned to perfection! I wished they gave you a second helping. It was just sooo good. Complements to their chef for a wonderful meal. 

The show was excellent and was roughly two hours in length. It wasn't just jousting. There was a storyline and competitive sport between the Knights of your choosing. I won't give all of the show away for fear of spoiling it but the sword fights were cool and as the swords clash and bang against each other you may even get to see some sparks fly! 

This my friends was worth the money along with the great show by the performers. If you can resist purchasing the add ons, it's definitely worth the trip. At least do it once! I would come back again but couldn't afford frequent visits as again this place can set you back. Parking is included in the price and the lot is behind the castle.

Went here for the first time, for a friend's birthday party this Saturday.  It was very crowded, as was expected.  The dinner consisted of; your choice of Coke, water, or ice tea, with alcoholic drinks available for an additional charge, tomato soup with garlic bread, chicken (which was too dry), corn on the cob, a baked potato, an apple turnover, and coffee.  The bar was very crowded before the show, and ordering just a single drink took very long.  For vegans, there is an alternative meal.  Not sure what it is, although I do know you get utensils.
     The show was entertaining.  The games were not overly difficult or impressive, but they do a great job of getting each section involved in cheering for their knight.  The final duels were good, a bit repetitive, but it seemed as though the performers got progressively better.
     The main drawback here was the price.  Over $70 per person for a sub par dinner and one drink each just can't be made up for by an hour and a half "show."  It wasn't terrible, and it was relatively fun, but I don't think I'd recommend it.  BTW, I did see somebody's vomit on the toilet while using the restroom.  So, yes, there are idiots who get THAT drunk at medieval times.

Another great night and another great show! We won two tickets from their Facebook page! So if you happen to have Facebook, like them and you'll see all their interesting giveaways and coupons! Because we won tickets, we purchased an additional two. Thursday's this month were only $32! You don't have to come here and have it cost an arm and a leg! 

Thursday night was the perfect time to go. It wasn't crowded, lots of kids at the show -- great for parents who are worried their kids won't sit still. You could hear the actual dialog 100 times better. The whole night had a calm feel to it! 

We received outstanding service from our "mench" man wench Josh. What a sweetheart he was! Food was great! Had a blast! Thank you medieval times for the wonderful opportunity! They have great giveaways so I suggest you like their page and participate. Real people win! ;)

I went here for my birthday and let me tell you...it was fun!  Great food, good show. Beer a little in the pricy side for the first one but you get to keep the stein. We were very pleased with our experience.

We've wanted to come since we were kids.  As adults, we still had an amazing time.  Bring out your inner nerd, buy a few frosty mugs of ale (albeit expensive at $16 plus $8 refills), and have a great meal with some extremely enjoyable entertainment.

You can hunt down some really inexpensive deals right now.  Our night was only about $40 a person (with tax) for the meal and show.  We're really not going to go into great detail, because most of the other reviews will tell you what the packages include.  Just know that we had a great time and we'll visit any of their nine castles again.

Really fun and unique experience! The food was surprisingly impressive and the show was entertaining. They have a full bar but drinks can get pretty pricey. There's a lot of fun activities and souvenir opportunities before the show so it's good to come early. I expected a really cheesy dining show but everything was a lot more fun and entertaining than I expected!

This place was amazing!
I didn't expect to have as much fun as I did when we came here.
I brought my 6 year old here. Everyone refered to us as "my lady and my lord" it definitely brought a smile to both us. 
The show was very entertaining and lots of fun.
The food was amazing. The half chicken tasted like greek lemon rotisserie. The dragon blood soup and the garlic bread was very tasty too. My son is very picky but he loved all the food.
Photos are a bit pricy but they do a really good job.
I looking forward to come next year again.
It's totally worth it.
The best medieval feasting experience in all of the realm! The food is great, the show exciting, and you're treated like royalty every time.

We purchased 7 tickets at the Great Lakes Navy Base at a significant discount and they also bumped us up to VIP for free for being military. Make sure you show up at least an hr early to look around, take pictures, use the bathroom, etc.

The show was fun, entertaining and they even threw a rose to my daughter during one of the acts. Our kids were playing with all their toys from the gift shop during and after the show. 

Food was mediocre, service was great and everyone was polite and in character at all times. Cocktails were expensive, but doable. 

Overall, great experience.

You know you want to give in.  Let loose.  Get lost in your surroundings here at Medieval Times.  This is neither the time nor place to take yourself seriously.

Once you've opened up, the experience here can be fantastic.  Get there early and get close parking as well as the opportunity to explore a little bit.  You can see the horses up close (but behind bars/windows).  Grab a slushie drink (about $8 for alcoholic version).  Visit the museum/dungeon where they have medieval torture devices ($2).  Or maybe just do a little shopping for capes, robes, swords, and other miscellaneous "Medieval" souvenirs.

A little presentation and next you're ushered into the arena by your knight's color.  The show itself is pretty impressive.  Lots of horse-riding, jousting, fighting, and a slightly cheesy backstory to go with it.  All in good fun.  Make sure to cheer for and wave to your knight and you might just get a flower.

Some tips, go during an off-peak night and you'll be able to sit closer (as well as increase your likelihood of getting a flower).  The food is good but no utensils are provided so be ready to dig in with your paws.

user_location: Salt Lake City, Salt Lake City, UT
review_text:
We came here for my dear boyfriend's 30th in August. The hotline employees were super helpful and I was able to reserve 10 discounted spots for our friends. We were running late so we kind of missed some of the beginning stuff but it doesn't seem like we missed much of pre-show activities. It appears that they just try to sell you photos and apparel and souvenirs before the show. Silly me brought this elaborate castle shaped cake I had handcrafted. The Medieval Times employees tried to offer to serve it to us during the dessert course but I refused because I wanted to show it off to my friends and do the traditional candles and song routine beforehand. After being ushered to our seats, we noticed that food service felt a lot like a wedding. There's one person for drinks, another person for soup, another for the "baby dragon", another for the dessert, and another for the booze orders and a different person who actually brings you drinks! It was all very confusing especially when it came time to figure out who to tip. When our server announced himself halfway through the meal, I was surprised that they even mess with the formality of having a "server". The show happened in darkness so on occasion I would spill food or drink on myself. Break out the bibs! As for the show itself, it was incredible! It was like if a Renaissance Faire had professional wrestling! The stunts were at times cheesy, but that didn't detract one bit from their impressiveness! In the end, I wasn't able to serve my cake in the dark chaos. Not that if I was given a chance it would have been an ideal setting for a birthday celebration. Everyone's seat is facing the stage and we were seated all in one row. Some people were able to get their special event announced. Not sure how they did that! We probably missed something at the beginning. After the show, the lights come on and everyone goes to the lobby to take photos and they try to sell you more souvenirs.

Overall this place is amazing. Definitely take advantage of online discounts. My two main criticisms are that it lacks "hangout vibes" and that the food they serve is completely historically inaccurate. Tomatoes, corn, and potatoes are all new world foods! If you're going to be that inaccurate, would it kill you to give me a fork?

I remember having the best time when I went here back in grade school. My fiance and I decided to go here randomly for a date night. A coworker had said she recently went and it was awful and cheesy but we stuck with our plans. The food was pretty good, nothing gourmet, but not bad at all. 

As for the actual show, of course it's over the top and exaggerated. If you're expecting anything other than that, well I don't have any words for you. It was a fun time that provided a night of entertainment. I would definitely come back to take my nephews or even recommend as a fun date night idea for others. 

It is pretty pricey if you go thru Medieval Times but there are always deals through Groupon and TravelZoo which is what we went with.

Fantastic!!!! One of the best experiences of my life! So exciting and entertaining! The food is fantastic. Everyone gets the same thing: tomato soup, garlic bread, roasted potato, corn on the cob, chicken and for desert an apple turnover! The show is amazing the actors are awesome. Totally worth the price.

My husband and I took our niece and nephew here for their golden birthday. I came up with the idea out of nostalgia and everything I remember was intact and spectacular. Now this would be a 5-star review but it is a little too pricey to have the best value and earn that fifth star. But the theatrics, service and food were outstanding. Seriously, the food was better than many typical restaurant's food-didn't expect that! 

Needless to say, my nephew (5yrs old) said as we left, "I want you and Uncle Matt to take us here for our birthday next year too." All I need to hear to spend the money again. ;) Such a cute comment and fun day.

Went with the family for the first time and everyone had an amazing time! 
The doors to the seating area open at 7:10 but they say you can get there at 6:15 when you make your reservation. If you do  get there really early, you're standing around for a while so be prepared for that. They have some things to look at and buy before you're seated but it's not enough to keep you busy for the whole (almost) hour wait. If I could do it over, I'd probably get there around 6:50. I went on a weekday. 
Once you're seated, you're greeted by a wench or man wench and they bring you something to drink and throughout the show, they bring you food. No complaints about the food! 
The show is pretty magical! You will get wrapped up cheering for your knight! Great family fun for everyone!!! 
It seems expensive but it's definitely  worth it!

What a wonderful place for entertainment for all ages.
This place is full of fun from the time you walk in the door. Everything is so well put together. 
The Drinks are good from the bar. 
It's  so many different light up toys. You are just going to have such a great time.
The service of the waiter's are just out standing 
You will feel like a Princess.
My son had a great time. (king) The food was finger licking good. And you get a lot of it. You get a full coarse meal Drinks and coffee and Dessert. 

Today was a good day Red and yellow was the winning knight. How cool.
The take home pictures are a little pricey but it's all worth it. 
This is a place for kids of all ages and party time or even just having some good family time. Get ready to cheer your lungs out and swing your team flag up high. 


Note :
Please leave a tip the staff is so wonderful

I have been here a few times, and every time was a great experience.  

The show itself is entertaining.  You are placed in a section with a color which represents your Knight.  You cheer for your knight as he competes in medieval games including jousting, sword fighting, and catching rings with his lance.  

I brought my 70 year old parents and my 4 and 8 year old children.  All had a wonderful time.  

The food is quite tasty.  You will get messy, there is no silverware, but nothing outrageous. 

My oldest was knighted before the show started.  For a little extra cash, I believe it was $30, he got his name called by the king to come up in front of everyone and knee down and be knighted.  This came with a picture with the king and a toy sword.  For even more money you can upgrade your sword, for adults.  

I would not pay extra for the medieval torture device tour.  It was not really worth it.  

On a side note, my father is wheelchair bound.  They took care of us immediately.  We were allowed to enter the arena first and select where to sit.  Although we were limited to the top floor area as we could not get down the stairs.  The staff assisted us every step of the way.

I have been meaning to check out this place for years! I saw a Groupon for it and thought what perfect timing. I bought the Royalty tickets and so glad I did! I didn't know what to expect when coming here. First you arrive and they crown you with a colored crown that will match with your seating area and which knight you will be rooting for. You then walk in and they have all these booths/stations setup for either drinks, souvenirs, photos, swords, etc. 

They do not open the doors to the arena till a certain time and once they do, someone will be there to escort you to your seats. With our royalty tickets we bought from Groupon, we scored front row seats! It was so perfect! I was surprised to see that they had such roomy and comfortable seats and in front of you is your table for eating. Along with the Royalty tickets you get a printed program and a behind the scenes DVD. The show was so much fun and it was so school to see everyone in character and the crowd going crazy over their knight! Our server was in character the whole time as well and the service and the food was great! It was a lot of fun for my son to eat with his hands! 

I was very pleased with everything and would recommend this to anyone who has kids to try it out once.

Although I was skeptical, medieval times turned out to be a fun outing! First, if you are planning on going I would recommend signing up for their emails or looking for discounts/savings codes. Thanks to an email I was sent we purchased tickets for $35/pp. Regularly tickets are 61.95/pp, which in my opinion is a "no" (LOL). Upon arriving to the castle is was pretty cool I enjoyed the theme! Before we entered the arena we opted to get drinks as they do have a full service bar. When we entered the arena it was soooo cool (I can't believe how easily impressed I am LOL) the horses were beautiful, the acting wasn't bad, and my team (#TEAMGREEN) won (whoohooo!). While watching the show you are served dinner. The menu is as follows; garlic bread, tomato soup, roasted chicken,  corn, potatoes, & "pastry of the Castle" which is like an apple turn-over thingy. The food was okay, and you don't get utensils -yes, you eat with your hands- but they give you wet naps. Medieval times was cool I would definitely recommend for a different type of night out! (Bring the kiddos as well!)

This was a "bucket list" item for my friend and me, so we hopped in the car one Saturday afternoon and drove up from Indy. 

Doors open 75 minutes before your event, and we got there right when the doors open, which we later realized was a good call as it got us and our friends really good seats. 

The staff has your check-in down to a science, and after three or four checkpoints, we were in the main hall. There are lots of little shops there that are more geared toward kids, but adults will still find fun things to look at. You can also check out the horses which are over by the dungeon. We didn't tour the dungeon, but there's a $2 tour fee. 

Entry to the pavilion was surprisingly organized given the sheer volume of people. We got in and got to our table pretty quickly, and then the show began! It was amazing and incredibly engaging. I worried it'd border on the cheesy, but it didn't. It felt as authentic as anything can feel when you're wearing a paper crown. 

The food was the biggest surprise - it was fantastic! You don't get silver wear, but it was t as messy as I imagined, plus you get ye olde wet nap at the end. 

Medieval Times met and exceeded my expectations. I look forward to coming back!

I took my son here yesterday, and it was my first time also. The show was very entertaining, the food was....meh.... It wasn't bad, just nothing really special. One bit of advice though, bring some cash to tip your server. I didn't really think about that, being that everyone gets the same thing kind of banquet style. It wasn't a big deal, just had to go get a beer to break a 20. Overall i was satisfied with the experience, but seems like more of an "every few years" kind of thing to me.
Had a great time!  Have a 5 and 7 year old and they loved it. Show was really good and food was as well, recommend upgrading to the VIP, our seats were amazing.

I can cross this off my "bucket list" but I won't be back anytime soon. 

For what you pay for, it doesn't seem worth it unless you get a deal (which they have plenty of). For about $74, you get ONE piece of what is obviously Texas Toast, a healthy sized portion of deliciously seasoned chicken, one little corn on the cob and some ok tomato soup. I thought we were suppose to get a spare rib based off the previous reviews but I guess not. I wished they could have at least given us two pieces of toast or a longer ear of corn, but whatever. Other than the chicken, they are kinda meager with their portions, even the slice of birthday cake was tiny.. 

The theater part was ok. It took them forever to get to the fighting part and when they did, our sorry ____ knight lost. After an hour, I was pretty much like the horses.....OVER IT. 

I don't like the fact you still gotta tip the servers (I was prepared to do so nonetheless) after paying that high ____admission price. For what I spent, there are better places to celebrate a birthday. I don't know what I was expecting but it wasn't the experience I had.

A blast from the past! Truly an amazing experience. Im a medieval junkie myself so this stuff clicked with me. I love the costumes and i marvelled with the show and performances. The theatrics and all were outstanding! I love the horse shows and im so amazed with the trained falcon. I love the combat and all, fantastico! They even sport this accent to be in character. Expect to get wowed if you are into these medieval stuff. 

My husband surprised me with this on our 1st Anniversay. And boy oh boy, im glad he did! We had the Royalty package and comes with it is a photo opt where you can wear costumes and select your preferred background and they give you the photo afterwards in a medieval themed frame, you get a DVD and a booklet with infos about medieval times, and you get front row seats which is i think the best seat to be at. 

The food was okay but they were tasty and portioned well. You get a medieval bread (garlic bread) with blood soup (tomato soup), baby dragon  (a big chunk of chicken) for the entree with baked potatoes on the side, and a medieval dessert (apple crisp or pie i think hehe). A friend tipped my hubby to bring utensils just in case but we were not aboe to use them. Besides the food were pretty much hand-able food. They definitely encourage you to use your hands as spoon(right hand) and fork (left hand). 

Over-all i absolutely enjoyed the whole medieval experience. Kids will love this place. I remember the father and son sitting next to us had made a funny remark; when the entree was served i heard the kid blurted out to his dad with so much excitemen: "Dad, i got the dragon's foot!" We all laughed but it was such a cute and funny moment. So this is a must-go for medieval geeks and fanatics like me. Game of Thrones-y anyone?

Had a great time here with a group of friends.  The acting was really good, and the staff was really friendly.  From start to finish it felt like we were in the show.  They do a really good job at getting people involved and ready for whats to come before you head into the theater.  

My friends and I all commented on how good the food actually was.  The portions were large and the chicken as well as everything else was cooked to perfection.  The only con is that if you want another beer/wine you have to leave the theater, so I recommend getting your cup filled before you go in.  Great place for a fun day or night!

My family and I had a great time here.    The atmosphere, entertainment, service, food and drinks were all excellent!  Especially the beer!  :-)   I had heard that there was no silverware before going here and though that it would lead to a big mess, but it didn't.    All the characters played there roles well and really kept up the atmosphere.    All in all, a very good experience that I would highly recommend to anyone.

Medieval Times was a thoroughly enjoyable experience. I would recommend this place to anyone with kids. The dinner and entertainment surpassed my expectations.  The "Feast" is a hands-on food experience, no utensils provided, you get a half of roasted chicken, a half of potato, a corn on the cob, a bowl of soup and an apple turnover over the course of the show. I was very satisfied with the food and how it was prepared.

The "Knights of the Round" Tournament was a great show for kids and adults alike. Much of the show was a display of horsemanship, but there was plenty of  swordplay and jousting. The crowd got noisy and rowdy as the night went on and hey, I did my fair share of cheering. Plenty of kids were having a great time waving their flags and enjoying the sparks fly as the knights fought to the death. 

In the lobby outside of the arena there is a gift shop with plenty of knick-knacks to buy. I really bought in to the ambiance Medieval Time tries to set. With tapestries hanging on the walls and painted coats of arms through out the lobby you really do feel like you are inside a castle. There is a bar in the lobby as well with the usual suspects of beer and wine on purchase.  Don't get carried away with buying stuff because purchases of everything in the lobby are pricey so focus on taking in the entertainment and food. 

Overall a wonderful experience, the staff was great and treated our group well. The food is what you would expect, tasty and filling. A great night out, a great birthday celebration.

This was perfect for a 2nd graders birthday. A VIP package for a family of four and one friend was the right price with coupon ($50 per adult and 30 a kid.) Be sure to arrive at least an hour before show time to take advantage of the waiting room which has a horse stable, different knight statues, two full bars, and a costume photo area. Also a king and his chancellor will put on a little floor show. It's a bit confusing how it all works so it helps to get in early and ask questions on how it all works. The VIP package includes a group photo in front of a green screen (you choose background) but costumes are $3 extra. I was a bit annoyed at that. 

The kids actually liked the food (so did the adults!). The tomato soup was decent, but the real winner was a really well roasted and seasoned quarter chicken. You also get a quarter cob and half a seasoned baked potato. An apple turnover for dessert. The VIP package includes a slice of birthday cake. 

FYI: Tip at least $5 a person.

Had an awesome night surprising my boyfriend for his 33rd birthday! You read that correctly: 33rd. Yes, this is a great experience even for adults - well worth the trip. Everyone in our group of 9 had an awesome & hilarious time at Medieval Times :) The food was pretty good, drinks were reasonably priced, staff was super friendly... Black & Yellow Knight 

We opted to take a van service to/from the castle, so no one had to be DD, and I would highly recommend this to others as well if you don't mind the added cost.
Its very cheesy in terms of the storyline but once you get past it, the food and beverages are great; the customer service is good for the amount of people that pass through there

So, it's dinner and a show.  If you like watching jousting and knights battling while eating with your fingers, this is the place for you!  If none of that sounds appealing, stay home - you won't have a good time.

The show was great - the Chancellor was awesome!  We were in the Blue Knight's section and had a ball.  There was a little seating confusion when we first got into the hall, but it was quickly resolved.

The food was fantastic and served by a very pleasant wench (she said it was OK to use that word there, just not at home to my wife).

The sales of blinking lighted and glow in the dark crap for the kids was a little annoying, but not so much that it took away from the show.

Very well organized considering the amount of people who were in attendance.  I don't know that we would go there with any regularity, but once a year or so sounds like fun.  That being said, it is like an hour drive for us to go there.

Our over all experience was good. We got out tickets on Groupon and then did the Royalty upgrade at the door. With the upgrade we got front row seating, which was nice! The food was flavorful and good size portions. The kids portions are the same as the adults even though you pay less for kids. My daughter who is 4 had a great time. Our blue knight was great and interacted with her. He even made her his queen of the tournament, which was cute! Our only complaint would be the pricing of the alcohol drink and the tickets to the museum. The tickets to the museum were $2/person, which doesn't seem like much, but the museum took maybe 2 mins and there wasn't anything interesting for kids. In my opinion the museum should be free or not there at all. Other then that we had a great time!

Medieval Times = HUZZAH HUZZAH HUZAAH for a most-wonderful entertainment & dinner for a group of ~1000!
As part of my conference taking place in Schaumburg/Chicago, we were provided transportation to/from Medieval Times and an entire show/dinner for ourselves, with the added bonus of the grand finale theme being a duel against our rival organization. The evening before, a handful of the knights and the king's right-hand man attended the first dance at our hotel and showcased a [well-choreographed] sword fight as a precursor to the evening ahead.
There was quite a buzz while we waited to be ushered into the stadium since we would be seated with our respective provinces. I would suggest not going into the Torture Museum since the explanations are fairly... graphic. 
The evening officially kicked off with the king's spokesman announcing our Grand President and his wife dressed in Medieval attire on the small stage in the waiting area- what a way to set the mood! As we're ushered in, the servants and wenches take your tickets, direct you to your area [my seat was thankfully first row], and quickly take any drink orders since they are part of the show initially. 
The show is pretty cool - the performers are great athletes, and the horses are amazing. At times it's a bit cheesy, but expected. I was elated when our Black & Yellow Knight advanced far into the tournament and threw me a flower; saddened though when he was killed by the eventual winner. The games and activities flow right into one another as does the meal - started out with dragon's blood, then a HUGE piece of dragon[chicken], 2 veggies and a pastry for dessert. Afterwards, all of the knights sit at their thrones for picture opportunities. All in all, a wonderful evening with 1000 friends!

Me- Can I have a fork?
Worker- What is this fork thy speak of my lord?  
Me- Can I have a Pepsi?  
Worker- Right away my lord.  

There are not too many places you can go where you eat with your hands & watch people sword fight.  If you go on a really good night you might get to see a drunk try & scale the net & jump in on the action.  

This place can be a little pricey but it is definitely fun.  It is always fun to walk around to the shops before the show starts.  It is always fun to get the birthday package & get your picture taken with your group.  

The show has changed over the years & they try top keep it fresh.  If you go with some friends this place can be a lot of fun.  The food here is also pretty good.  The servers stay in character so you can't ask for a fork.  

Overall the prices can be a little high but the food is good & it is a fun place to go.  I would definitely come here again.

Like many have posted, they frequently offer deals, so for my moms birthday we got half price tickets by looking around! My 3 year old daughter dressed as a princess and the reaction from staff and other diners had a smile on her face before we even took our seats.

Souvenirs are overpriced as are adult beverages, but come on, this is the equivalent of going to a Cubs game. My major gripe was only being allowed to buy one alcoholic beverage at a time when lines are long and a beer is 8 bucks.  

The staff was fantastic. Our 'wench' was fantastic and engaged my daughter. We bought a light up wand and later during the show a guy selling something entirely different said it needed new batteries and took it and brought it back. It was much brighter! What a thoughtful thing to do.

The food is good. I remarked to my family that I have attended a dozen weddings where the chicken isn't half as moist as this. I expected a child's serving for my 3 year old and she was given the same portion as us. I thought I would eat what she didn't, but the portions were so large we brought home enough to feed her another meal which was a pleasant surprise.

All in all, look for deals to defray ticket prices. Treat it like any sports/theme park for the extras. A great time and I've been here probably a half dozen times over the last 20 years and the show changes. The smile on my daughters face while spending time with her nana made this a truly special day.

Simple but good food. The performance was a little cheesy, however, seemed like the kids absolutely loved it. Got a coupon online so, ended up spending around $34 per ticket. Honestly, I don't think it was worth $60 per person. Overall, my husband and I had a great time. The horses were amazing!!! I was just a little worried that one of them might get hurt. I would like to come back here again, with my whole family this time

What an awesosme time we had...front row.....woohoo..My son felt like a Prince since it was his birthday celebration. the food was outstanding, the staff excellent, the horses magnificent and the Knights were very entertaining...

This place you have to visit once, albeit I think it is overpriced, it is a ton of fun. 

I was done here for work with some colleagues - we had a few days for a conference that we were in town for so we had to book the tickets. We sat in the first row and got the full experience. We had mead and the giant leg of turkey to eat. There are no utensils so be prepared to eat with your hands. 

We had a "manwench" as he called himself. After starting we get into the games that we came for. I couldn't help but get flashbacks to watching Cable Guy and thinking we would somehow be selected from the crowd for some games but that never happened. 

I can't even explain how much fun all of this was to attend. Would I go back, probably not, yet is worth it to do once.

If you are looking for a different type of group outing packed with cheesy entertainment (in dinner-theater form) (and real horses), don't look elsewhere because Medieval Times has it covered. I went here with my family on a Sunday afternoon.  My 2 year old nephew loved it!  This seems to be a very popular place to celebrate birthdays of all ages - IT'S NOT JUST FOR THE KIDS!!   For almost 3 hours, you can expect to be well-fed (although you must be comfortable eating with your hands as they did in medieval times?), and be addressed by the server as "My Lord/My Lady- our server did this. If you really want to get into it, wear your complimentary crown!

Occasionally somebody will walk by selling overpriced swords and flags that the kids might enjoy.  

FOOD:  I was surprised at how good the food was.  Garlic bread to start, tomato soup, roasted chicken aka Dragon's Wing, mashed potatoes, Bbq ribs, and for dessert: a delicious peach strudel!

There's a bar outside the arena, but you can also order alcohol from your server.

There are plenty of bathrooms too which I appreciated - just don't go at the end of the show or you can expect to wait for a very long time.  

And don't forget to tip your server at the end of the meal.  It looks tough serving food with all those stairs!

Overall a fun group experience!

The first time I came here was for my senior trip in 2006.  I returned for a radio event on 4/12 and wasn't sure what to expect.  IT. WAS. AMAZING.  I haven't stopped talking about it to my friends and family.  I am already planning to get everyone together to go for my birthday in June!  The show was so fun to watch and cheer for our knight.  Our server was AWESOME.  I can't remember his name to save my life but he was in the Blue 8 section, tall guy with a beard/goatee.  The food was better than I thought it would be.  The chicken was so juicy and flavorful.  I wish the soup had been a bit colder so that I could have eaten it all, it was very good.  The potato was a bit dry and under salted but still pretty good.  It was also awesome to meet the knights after the show.  We got to talk to our knight and take a picture with him.  I can't wait to go back!!
Love everything about Midieval Times!! Excellent place to take the kids and watch a good show, so worth it. Best place to spend my 35th birthday. We'll be back for our anniversary, loved it.

Let's see. Yes the fighting is choreographed. No, they will never break away from chicken being the main dish being served. The story is still the same story I saw approximately 7 years ago...in a different city. So no, not something you do every chance you get. However,  if there are little ones in your family. Make it a a few years kinda thing you do with your buddies for traditional sake. Maybe then I would say it was worth it. So why the third star...I'm still a kid at heart and where else can you yell "serving wench" and not get in trouble.
Won tickets the other night from Facebook! Had an amazing night! The food was delicious and our waitress was wonderful.

Once in a lifetime is enough for this place. Very interesting experience. I wish I would have bought my own silverware as I had to pick apart my chicken and my children's chicken. Not sure how silverware is any more modern than the light up led wands they sell. Pretty pricy and could use some updating inside. 4 stars is only because my children and husband had and absolute blast.

Do not go to this place if you are a stiff person with no imagination or exotic new things. Was my first time going yesterday for my boyfriend's birthday and I can say it was definitely a great experience we both will remember forever. Can't wait to go back with friends to share the fun, also note you don't need to be a kid or have kids to enjoy this place.
When I went I had a great time!!  The food was actually good and the show was pretty fun!!  I would def go again anytime

Where do I even start. Went here for a friends birthday party, we brought 50+ people and we were hassled the ENTIRE night by the manager and his minions. We weren't allowed to cheer, we were "cheering too loud" for our Knights. We pretty much took up an entire section. The entire group was cut off from drinking and we were all kicked out had to wait in the cold for our bus. Trust me I know obnoxious annoying drunks but we were far from being belligerent. It's apparently a "family" show so don't go with your friends unless you plan on being silent. Also, show wasn't great. Kind of boring and bland. Maybe if it was more interesting people wouldn't have to conversate over the show. Food was mediocre not filling so don't turn to alcohol to help fill your tummy or you won't be there much longer.
So many years since I've been here.  I remember the experience was like non other. Very exciting and entertaining. The food was tasteless but it coordinated with the time theme.

I've been wanting to check this place out since 2001, and I finally went today with my husband and dad... It was a time well spent. 
At first I thought that even with the coupon, it's still expensive; however, after taking funny pictures in costumes,  eating a filling meal, and watching a fabulous show,  it's really not that expensive after all. Especially if you think about how much care they need to give to the horses and falcon. 
I would 100% recommend it, but it's definitely a once in a lifetime thing. No need to go several times.

Ye Olde Touristy Trappe

Some things never change.  And sometimes that's a good thing, because they were always cool from day one.  Point in case: Medieval Times.

Everyone knows what's in store for them when they buy tickets to this nationwide dinner theater chain.  Lots of fanfare, actors wearing costumes and talking in pseudo-old English accents, jousting, sword fights, utensil-less food, and wenches serving ale.  I hadn't been to a MT in over a decade, but I was glad to see that not much had changed.

The exterior facade is huge and built to look like a castle (obviously), and the inside is vast, consisting of the main arena and pre-show staging area, where you can spend outrageous amounts of money on tacky souvenirs.  Okay, not all of them are tacky and expensive--like the awesome stainless steel goblet I bought for only $10--but is buying a light up sword for $35 really worth your kid's happiness?  Can't answer, not a dad.....yet.

All of the actors stayed in character and did a commendable job rousing the crowd.  As a thespian myself, I can appreciate the effort the king & company put into their performances.  However, several of the knights seemed bored, and a couple looked downright unhappy.  The green knight was far and away the best, always smiling and nodding to our section when his horse trotted past.  Thankfully, he was the dude we got to cheer on!

The food was satisfactory.  A little on the anemic side, perhaps, but tasty enough.  Good garlic bread, TINY portion of soup, bland roasted potato wedges, tasty BBQ ribs, and a decent turkey/chicken leg (whatever, meat-on-a-stick).  The flaky pasty dessert--basically an apple turnover--was a nice way to cap off things.  Service was fine, but I had to laugh when the waitress/wench offered us more "Medieval Pepsi" or something equally silly (they couldn't just call it 'Cola of the Castle'?)  Booze prices were pretty inflated, so I passed.

The highlights were jousting and sword fights among the knights.  While there were a couple instances where the knights fell/jumped off their horses (to simulate getting 'knocked off' by the joust) and it looked phony, the majority of stage combat was actually very good.  When they clashed swords, sparks literally flew!  I also loved to see the knights using flails and shields as weapons.

Here's the TL;DR version--I had fun.  Yeah, it's pretty gimmicky and not particularly cheap, but it's just as enjoyable as I remember it as a wee lad.  I would happily return.

Protip: the Orlando, FL location has a working drawbridge and a moat!  Step up your game, Schaumburg MT!

In no way authentic, but a blast none the less.

In fact the lack of authenticity may be what gives the experience it's charm.

Go for the show, the food is a convenient addition to the show price, and sit back and prepare to cheer at the jousting and sword battles and ooh and awe like a little kid at the gorgeously trained horses.

Meanwhile, you can giggle at: 
- Some of the HORRID fake accents (excluding the main guy and the king who thankfully don't sound like a freshman drama class)
- Being called My Lord / My Lady by people who voluntarily call themselves your wench
- Repeatedly adjusting your ridiculous paper crown
- Eating (with your hands) a meal composed of 25% ingredients available in medieval times / 75% not available until well after America was discovered (namely: potatoes, corn, tomatoes and garlic)

Revel in fruity drinks like the Dragon Slayer (mango slushie and coconut rum) and settle back for an awesome show.

Waiting for the show to start is smart on their side. Have the public waiting for the show while buying liquor and attraction items.

The food is good i expected mashed potatoes but it was decent.
The horse and knights are definitely worth checking out!!!

I've been to medieval times many times.  Enjoyed it since I was young.  Rather than going to a restaurant and just eating, here you get to eat well and see a cool show!  I've been rather lucky my knight has won like 75% of the times I've attended!  The food is great, like seriously!  Last time I attended there wasn't a rib, in the past there was always and I enjoyed that.  But the 'normal' meal I've had here is garlic bread, tomato soup, potato, chicken, & rib (or something else now), and also a desert which is usually an apple pie type thing.  Plan to eat with your hands, because you don't get silverware!  I enjoy this, some people may not, but they do give you towels at the end of the meal also.  Overall, it's just a fun place to visit every now and then.  5 stars because I have had 0 problems and nothing to complain about.

 Some things to know:
1. Drinks are expensive.  Kind of like at a movie theater, the prices are very high for drinks, so plan on that, or plan on not drinking a lot.
2. There are deals!  Never pay full price for your tickets!  Check online and find a coupon code!
3. For children & families the earlier show times are best.  The later show times are best for a few buddies and drinking and yelling!
4. Don't bother paying extra for 'priority front row seating'.  I actually prefer sitting a couple rows back, and there are no bad seats in this place, all the seats are pretty much equal!

We took my mother there for her birthday this weekend,  our waiter Chris was great. The food was more than enough, hot, and delicious! 

Chris was very efficient and prompt with any additional request that we had. 

The show was different from the 1st time we went, longer even. 

My family and I had a great time!

This was the first time attending Medieval Times, and for me as a young adult, I really enjoyed it!  I got my ticket off of Groupon, so I only paid for dinner and tip for approximately $40 (which I hear is a much better deal than others had to pay).  I don't think I would have paid if it was more than $50.

The food was pretty decent.  I did not care for the tomato soup, but everything else was good.  I was worried about the fact that there was no utensils, but they gave out hand wipes.  Thank goodness!  I was filled with what was given to me.  I had garlic bread toast, soup, half a chicken (it seemed that big!), half of a potato, and some apple pastry.  

I enjoyed the show.  The knights fought, did some tournament things, etc etc.  I know the kids really enjoyed it, the ones next to us was really getting into it (they were SUPER upset that our team's knight lost... then they started to cheer for the bad guy.  My goodness).  I personally was worried that someone or one of the horses was going to get hurt, but nothing went wrong during the show.  I'm sure they have veterinary medical staff available for the animals, since they have so many horses.  

Overall a great experience for children. I wish women were able to be the knight though, that would have been great!

So much fun! 

I can't give it 5 stars because of the nagging feeling I have that the horses are subjected to abject cruelty...if not in the form of daily beatings, then at least by being forced to endure the canned earnestness of their ponytailed passengers, and their dramatic soliloquies and overall grandiosity. 

I bring this up because I swear that, during the evil knight's speech about his king destroying this kingdom, etc., his horse rolled his eyes like a million times.

The food was actually really tasty!

I liked being called m'lady.

Medieval Times makes for a fun date/outing/party/etc. if you're willing to fork out some cash. I will say, don't go frequently, the routine pretty much stays the same (I think it changes every 5 years or so), but it really is entertaining. Beautiful horses, men in tight pants, a stubborn falcon, finger food, the royal party, and all the things you can buy. 
    They say arrive early for various reasons (lines, getting seated, wanting you to buy stuff before the show, some routines done in the lobby, pictures), and upon arrival they do give the option to upgrade tickets. There are various levels of tickets, the basic package all the way to the several hundred dollar meet-the-king-get-knighted-fancy-cup-blah-blah-blah package. Check Groupon and elsewhere, you can often find some deals.
    The food is pretty good: some toasted bread, tomato bisque, a good portion of chicken, a sparerib, a potato, pepsi or ice tea, coffee, an apple turnover thing, and there is also a vegetarian option. Hopefully I didn't forget anything... it's eaten with your hands, btw, so don't look for utensils (hakuna matata, they give you wet naps). Our server was very nice, don't be a cheapskate with your tip, remember, they have to run around that arena with tubs of food for a whole row, they are probably paid like a server, which means not a lot so they rely on those tips.
    The show is fun. They have the different events and the horses really are beautiful. Have fun cheering for your team! They don't force you to participate but seriously, you're at Medieval Times, you've already lost some cool points showing up so lose a few more. The falcon was neat, as well. He was stubborn for awhile and wouldn't come down from his perch, I of course was on his side. The announcer for the evening was fantastic, love his voice, perfect for the role. 
    If you want an interesting insight on Medieval Times, Google the Reddit thread of Q's and A's by an old employee, it's pretty neat! There are other locations around the country, but this one is right off of the I-90 and Roselle Rd exit in Schaumburg.

Do you enjoy being squeezed in to a seat so small that the stranger next to you elbows you a dozen times? Do you enjoy keeping your bag between your feet because if you hang it off your chair the rude waitstaff will trip over it and dump Pepsi down your collar, then get mad at you? Do you enjoy bland, watery, luke warm tomato soup served in a ladle? Do you enjoy eating a dry, salty, half a chicken, with your hands, to the smell of horse shit? Do you enjoy eating half a salty shriveled potato, and a chewy, rubbery half an ear of corn? Do you enjoy a crap, predictable, floor show with the stage combat expertise of a middle school production of Camelot? Do you want to pay $50 each for the right to experience this all while wearing a paper crown? Then enjoy MEDIEVAL TIMES!

I had a family emergency in the middle of the show that made me step out for a second, where I inadvertently wandered into an employee area taking a phone call. This military looking dude, who I later found out was the general manager, Kevin Gadberry, literally starts yelling at me saying, 'Do you work here?!' (he obviously knew I didn't) then VIOLENTLY told me to 'GTFOH' as he stood an inch from my face. WTF??? Why would he treat a paying customer, who obviously made an honest mistake, so threateningly?? Ruined a night out with my family. 1 star for the rest of the staff being generally enthusiastic, a cool show, and decent food. But I can't help but think if I was a middle aged white guy like Kevin Gadberry is, would he have treated me differently? Smh go at your own risk PoC.

It has been over 15 years since I have been here, I was a teen at the time and had a blast with my aunt. Now I am here with my husband and our 3 year old. I am surprised to see how much this is an adult cocktail type of thing as much as a family thing but I am happy to say the party didn't take away from the family experience we were expecting. 

Great show, good food - just as I remember from when I was a kid.

This weekend I went to Medieval Times for my 5th time....but 1st time with kids! I gotta say the whole experience takes on a whole new vibe when tiny people are involved & no liquor is present. My nieces had an awesome time and the experience was well worth it - but it's a one time thing. You won't catch me taking the little ones back there and the main reason is how things add up.

The wait to get in was very confusing & pretty horrendous. I wasn't sure what line I was supposed to be in so we picked a random line. It was a mighty long wait to get in. We arrived at the recommended time of 630pm for the 730pm show & ended up waiting about 30 minutes in various lines until we got into the actual castle's main hall. We had pre-printed our tickets so we bypassed a huge lineup of humans waiting to buy.

After we got inside, my nieces asked me, so what do we do now!? haha Poor little girls don't understand all the waiting involved at the castle. The whole thing reminded me of waiting at Disney World except if you're a good planner, you can get away with no waiting at Disney. Sadly at Medieval Times, there's no avoiding all the crazy lines & waiting around. 

We went up to the gift area and looked over their offerings. I'm the cool, fun Aunt so was planning on letting them each get a light up, flashy thing. One girl picked a sound making light up wand & the other picked the sword that lit up in three places. Fancy! $38 fancy. Also, for all purchases at Medieval Times you have to show your ID (apparently a new policy) and I didn't have mine on me. Thankfully I had a couple of 20 spots so I could fork over the cash. So...

Pro-Tip: Bring Cash for souvenirs and tips. It just makes life easier here.

The show itself was quite entertaining, well most of it. We sat in the Black & White section at the very end and the little ones complained about not being able to see well. They couldn't see the King & Princess at all and had a hard time seeing all the action. The beginning of the show was a bit confusing to them but they loved seeing the horses though all I could think about was how I hope they are treated well when not performing. The main actor/narrator guy is absolutely the star of the show and so fantastic! Great accent, on point facial expressions, he really gets into it and just is perfect in the role. The real action of the show comes in when the protective net comes down and the knights start battling. On guard!!! 

My nieces loved the show save for some complaints about viewing things. They also said a lot of the loud noises during the battle got a little scary (huge spiked balls banging against shields & a man snapping a whip, in particular). So if you have children scared of fireworks and things of that nature, this may not be the show for them.

Our waitress was very attentive and my nieces loved being called 'lady' and 'princess'. I caught her making a few little side comments which made me laugh and were more adult intended. I went with the vegetarian option for dinner which included a starter of hummus, pita bread, celery & carrots - pretty standard fare but the pita bread was warm and delicious. The main course had changed since the last time I went - a stew served in a metal pot of rice, veggies and what seemed to be beans, with a little packet of hot sauce on the side. It was a decent meal but any time the word 'decent' is used to describe something, it means it left something to be desired. After seeing my nieces' plates full of chicken, BBQ, potatoes and tomato soup, I will definitely be getting the normal meat eaters' meal on my next visit. The pastry was served hot & flaky with a warm apple center. I quite liked it and found it to be completely sufficient for dessert.

While having dessert, they came around to show us our picture we took with the Princess when we entered the castle. It was just SO cute, I couldn't resist forking the money over for it. $20 for 1 or $30 for 2. They must just bank on these expensive photos. I paid the $20 so my nieces could have a nice little memory of the three of us there and they appreciated it.

Tipping is the most confusing thing at Medieval Times. Yes, you need to tip. How much is the question? 20% of the tix price would be ridic. I paid $20 not knowing what was right. I've read people tip nothing to $2-$6 pp so in the future I will stick with just $5 or 6 pp. It's also a bit awkward outright telling your server how much tip you are giving them if you charge it.

So is Medieval Times fun? Heck yes it is!
But do they try to gouge every last cent from their guests? Heck yes they do.
$20 for the photo, $38 for a sword & a scepter, $20 tip and the tickets themselves cost $115, with a coupon code mind you.
Of course if you were to get drinks or anything else, that would just add more to the costs. 

$193 for 2 hours of fun makes it a once every 5 years type of activity!

Food: 5 
I hate when trendy restaurants are too cool for condiments, but I definitely get it after eating here. Their menu is not huge, but when you do what they do as well as they do it you don't really need to offer much of a variety. Slow roasted and succulent, they have the type of dragon leg that you can just tell the chef de cuisine puts his heart and soul into each and every night. Sides include a perfectly seasoned potato, phenomenal garlic bread, and corn on the cob that literally melts in your mouth. (once you get it off the cob) Culinarily my dining companions and I were more than pleased with this foodie haven.

Service:3
Unfortunately they lose 2 stars here. :-( Our server was very pleasant and seemed to know the menu like the back of his hand, but sadly was somewhat hard to flag down. He did have quite a few other tables though so i guess its understandable when a popular place gets as busy as they were on our visit.

Ambiance:2 
Retro. Very retro. Seriously, the 1800s called and they want their everything back. Not really sure where they were going with this decor, but if the scents coming from the kitchen weren't as tantalizing as they were I may have lost my appetite.

Overall: 3 1/2
I'd definitely come back. Even though there are a few aspects I'm not totally thrilled about the place is great for groups and you know it's authentic cause absolutely every staff member spoke with an accent.

I hadn't been to Medieval Times since 6th grade ( over 15 years ago) & I remember having such an awesome time with my classmates. Years passed and I've always wanted to go back. I wondered if it would still be as fun as I remembered & if the food was any good. I would go on the Medieval Times website from time to time and check out the prices and feel a strong sense of nostalgia as I would browse the photos yelp.  The prices seemed ridiculously high to me ($228.96 for two adults and 2 children ages 5 & 7) so I never felt it was worth it. Then it happened. Easter 2015 was two days away and I had no plans. We usually have Easter celebrations at our home with egg hunts, basket swapping and lots of food ,drinks and family. This year I wanted to avoid the whole cooking, cleaning and being the host & wanted to do something just my hubby, kids & I. So I Googled Medieval Times coupons and tried the first one I saw which was buy one ticket get one free! It went through and my total was $149 for 4 tickets on Easter Sunday. I was so excited and thrilled that I was going to share this experience with my kids but silently  hoped that after 15 years the show hadn't gotten shitty. So Eater morning the boys have no idea that they are going to the castle. After they found their baskets and had breakfast we all got showered and ready. Every time the boys asked where we were going, we repeatedly told them we were going to  "have a jousting-ly good time." They were pretty annoyed. Then they seen the castle and they were like " MOM! DAD! Look a castle!!" My husband and I exchanged smiles  as we pulled in the parking lot and the boys realized this IS where we were going. We bought our tickets online so we passed the line of people who didn't and walked right into the waiting area. As mentioned in all the other reviews there are a lot of souvenirs you can buy along with booze. My husband & each asked the bartender what the strongest drink was and she said the Royal Knight which was very good and we got to keep the souvenir cup it came in. $14 for the first round and then refills are $8. We bought the kids each a light up sword for $24 each (ouch) and the yellow flag to cheer on our yellow knight was $2. We arrived about 45 minutes early and the wait for the show to start did not even feel that long. I suggest coming as early as possible if you want decent seats. Once seated at our table our "wench" came along and offered drinks and talked a little about the food we were to be served. Her service was just OK. A different wench that's exclusively for alcohol came along and asked if we wanted to order another cocktail. We  asked her the same question we asked the bartender when we first arrived, " what is your strongest drink"? She stated the long island was the strongest and best so we ordered it. Big mistake do not order it! It tasted like a cup of lemonade, way too much sweet and sour! My husband even left his seat during the show to exchange our drinks for the royal knight drink and we stuck with that the remainder of the night. There was a lot of food and my husband was surprised that it was actually very good. They no longer serve the rib and now serve buttered corn in its place. While I thought the show itself could have been better, I was pretty content with how happy my kids were, how good the food was and my cocktail lol. When we left my children said it was the best Easter ever. So there ya go. Best Easter ever for kids

We took our 2 grandkids for our grandson's 6th birthday and it was a great time.    They LOVED it and we did too actually.   The food was really good, surprising since there are so many people, but very tasty.     We got there as the doors opened, so we got great seats.   Our knight didn't win, but we loved him anyway since he threw a carnation to our grand daughter!The staff was amazing and very helpful.    It is a great place to go and a great show

You always see the castle when you drive down I-90 west and you wonder what all the rave is about.  If you've never been there I suggest getting a small or large group and make an event out of it.  Instead of doing the same boring thing like going to a bar, stop into medieval times!  The food was not that bad, chicken leg, garlic bread and soup, apple turnover and a rib.  It was not that bad at all.  If you're a vegetarian no worries they have soup and veggies for you plus I believe some hummus. I posted a picture of all the food.  The tickets were pretty cheap but I ended up spending over $100 on drinks!  My friends and I had a blast! You don't go there for the food or drinks, go for the experience.  It's not like I'm going to be planning an event to come here every year but once maybe every 5 to 6 years seems ideal!

I've been here twice this summer, so I saw the same show twice, although they do periodically change it. I'm an adult and I have only ever come here with adults, and I still have a good time. The trip into the dungeon is worth it - it's like $2 or something. And as long as you can restrain yourself from buying tons of souvenirs, the price is good overall. The only time I ever paid full ticket price was part of a birthday package. But, please, don't ever pay the full price for tickets. You can buy them discounted everywhere- Groupon, Craigslist, all over. 
The food is alright, and one thing I have to really commend this place for is their ability to accomodate food allergies. One of my friends can't eat at most restaurants because they cook everything on the same stoves, cross-contaminate utensils and countertops, etc. My friend can actually eat here without getting sick, which is probably why he keeps having parties here. You can also get vegetarian (not sure about vegan) options. 
If you have a couple drinks at the bar before the show, you'll probably leave feeling pretty full and satisfied. The extra cake and virgin daiquiri you get in the birthday package is almost too much. 

I swear, the black and white knight always loses, though, what's up with that?

Good Clean Fun!  Food was good and the show was very entertaining.  Fun for kids and adults alike.  Can be pricey if you don't buy online with a retail me not coupon.  With the discount 40 bucks a head is an awesome price for dinner and a show.  I went with a group of 10 for an adult birthday party, but will return again to take my son.

great experience!!!
We were a bit late so we our seat at row 24 but our section had no one on their first row so we got upgraded!!! our server was so nice and helpful and made sure we were taken care of.  I wish I remembered his name.The food was really good and flavorful. I had a pina colada, that was kinda blah, too sweet for me. The castle itself is amazing and the show was very thought out. we really enjoyed it.  even My mom who doesn't speak english knew who she was cheering for.  Definitely look forward to coming back.

So I took advantage of a coupon that I received and thought I would check this place out. I probably would agree with some other Yelpers that I would not have paid full price.

I must say, I was pleasantly surprised. It was a fun and different experience that my whole family enjoyed. 

The food was good, better than I expected actually. I didn't like the no utensil rule, so I asked the waitress if she could bring some to us. Luckily, they have some plastic flatware for people who need it.

I don't think there's a need to do this more than once, though!

My wife and I are huge fans of renaissance faires, and we go to Medieval Times to give us our fantasy fix during the winter months. I've been going to Medieval Times for nearly twenty years, and have always had a great time as both a kid and as an adult. 

If you wait for a promotion (which happens pretty often), the experience is pretty reasonably priced. Last year my wife and I took advantage of the Valentines Day deal, which gave us each a glass of wine, a framed photo, dungeon tour, and a bunch of knick-knacks for $99, in addition to the full meal and show. Just keep checking their website and Facebook, and you'll eventually come across a great deal. 

The castle itself is well decorated and fun to explore. The staff is all dressed up and in character. Everyone who works there has been pleasant and helpful in my experience. 

The food is surprisingly excellent! I'm a vegetarian, and was quite happy with my hummus/veggie plate and 5-bean stew. I remember the chicken being tasty as well, during my meat eating days. Our waiters have always been friendly, quick and accommodating. 

The tournament itself is pretty spectacular. The actors are obviously very well trained, and put on an impressive performance of horsemanship and stage combat. A different house wins each time, and I always find myself grinning and laughing as I cheer on my favorite knight as he battles "to the death". 

I recommend Medieval Times to anyone. It's a great time all around that you'll remember for years to come!

Omg what a disappointment. My wife was asking me for years to go I finally gave in. My instinct was right. First off we waited 45 min in a crowd so tight we couldn't turn around while they gave their stupid speech and then tried to call in certain people by colors even though we couldn't move. It was beyond stupid from there it only got worse. Bad food horrible show the Knights looked like 98lb girls was embarrassing. I'm ashamed I was even there. Do not waste your money on this disaster. I would rather sit in court for two hours than sit through that again. They should change the name from medieval times to mediocre times. I've had more fun getting a tooth pulled than that joke. Fire everyone and close. You owe me 2 hours of my life back

Two of my grad school colleagues just finished some major exams and wanted to celebrate by going to Medieval Times.

To be honest, it was kind of crappy:

Pros:
- The whole place seemed fairly well-run.  It was clean, things started on time, and servers were courteous and professional.

- Having read the reviews I expected that the food would be awful.  It really wasn't.  The chicken was actually pretty good and the portions were certainly ample.  The Texas Toast, though, was worse than the frozen stuff I can get in the supermarket and the hilarious single rib was fatty and bland.

Cons:
- The show was nothing to write home about.  Over the course of nearly two hours, I didn't see a single thing that made me say, "Wow!  How'd he do that?"  I would say that the knights are competent at best.  They can ride horses.  They can do some reasonably passable choreographed sword fighting.  But they don't really do any stunts and I don't see how they could with the size of the arena.  

Maybe the falconry exhibition would have been cool if the falcon hadn't decided to perch up in the ceiling for a minute or two while the king awkwardly ad-libbed.  Actually, that was kind of funny.

- As everyone has mentioned, the tips should be included in the price of admission.  The way they're doing it now is obnoxious.

- I'm pretty sure they threw in a completely random and unexplained $8 "processing fee" when I reserved the tickets on their website.  

- Drinks were weak (although not quite as ridiculously expensive as I expected).  

- There is absolutely no reason to show up anywhere close to an hour early.  We walked in five minutes before the start time and we were fine.

Miscellaneous
- There's one thing I don't really get about this operation.  As far as I can tell, this show is really aimed at a seven or eight year-old.  But then it really gets quite violent at the very end, which is sort of jarring. They also don't seem to have a kid's meal option.  What little kid needs half a chicken, a rib, a bowl of soup, bread, and dessert?  It's really kind of weird.

Sadly enough, i live 15 minutes away from medieval times and last week was my first time EVER going (keep in mind that i'm 23)
My boyfriend found a groupon, so we went and we werent expecting the food to be great because his dad kinda put in our heads that it wasnt anything special.
On the contrary, the food was good! better than what we were expecting, on the plus side, YOU EAT WITH YOUR HANDS, awesome.

What i liked
- eat with your hands duh
-you get to keep the cups you get with your alcoholic drinks.
-horses are awesome
-all the knights have long hair
- everyone speaks like they're from Asgard (Thor, come on people)

What I didnt like
-Sitting front row, squished between people. the lady next to me spilled her beer on me :-(

overall, its really cool, definitely something you should experience especially since there aren't that many medieval times in the country.
A good thing to bring your kids to!
I enjoy coming here every few years. It hasnt changed much time to time but still overall an enjoyable experience. The food is good, the jokes corny, and the crowd is pretty energetic.

JOUST ON! 

Dost thou knowest the time?  "MEDIEVAL TIMES: DINNER AND TOURNAMENT" time! Let us go tither!

I was following my social media & saw the venue had awesome Medieval Times, "Joust for the Cause" t-shirts.
